sentence.text: Are HIV positive patients resistant to statin therapy?
Patients with HIV are subject to development of HIV metabolic syndrome characterized by dyslipidemia, lipodystrophy and insulin resistance secondary to highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART)
Rosuvastatin is a highly potent HMG-CoA reductase inhibitor
Rosuvastatin is effective at lowering LDL and poses a low risk for drug-drug interaction as it does not share the same metabolic pathway as HAART drugs
This study sought to determine the efficacy of rosuvastatin on lipid parameters in HIV positive patients with HIV metabolic syndrome
Secondary analysis examining the effectiveness of rosuvastatin monotherapy (n = 70) vs
rosuvastatin plus fenofibrate (n = 43) showed an improvement of 21
3% in TG and a decrease of 4
1% in HDL-C in the monotherapy group
The rosuvastatin plus fenofibrate showed a greater drop in triglycerides (45
001) and an increase in HDL of 7
This study found that rosuvastatin is effective at improving potentially atherogenic lipid parameters in HIV-positive patients
The lipid changes we observed were of a smaller magnitude compared to non-HIV subjects
Our results are further supported by a small, pilot trial examining rosuvastatin effectiveness in HIV who reported similar median changes from baseline of -21
In light of the results revealed by this pilot study, clinicians may want to consider a possible resistance to statin therapy when treating patients with HIV metabolic syndrome
